newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares close off highs on profit-booking.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares close off highs on profit-booking.

text.p: Bombay shares ended off their day's highs on Friday as a strong rally lost some steam when speculators booked profits near close, traders said.

Bombay's benchmark stocks index -- which hit a 1997 high of 4065 points in afternoon trade -- ended 41.23 points higher at 4024.18 as wary speculators unwound positions ahead of a possible oil price hike this weekend.
The decision-making panel of India's ruling United Front has not yet agreed on whether to meet on June 15 to take a decision on oil prices, a United Front spokesman said on Friday.
"There is no decision yet on holding the meeting on Sunday," spokesman Jaipal Reddy told Reuters. "I cannot say it will be held."

Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral and Finance Minister P. Chidambaram have said they favour increases in petroleum product prices, while left parties in the coalition want alternatives to be considered.
A decision has been deferred several times already and a meeting was earlier scheduled for Sunday.
Traders said foreign funds and speculators were buyers in frontliners like ITC, MTNL, Tata Tea and TELCO.
"It's been a mix of fund buying and local players also jumping along," said Maulik Sharedalal, a member-broker of the Bombay bourse.
Profit-booking towards close pared gains, traders said.
"Some selling from local insitutions and squaring off from speculators on the last day of the account drove prices lower towards the end of the session," said a trader at a foreign brokerage.
Shares of Reliance Industries bucked the uptrend and closed 4.0 rupees lower at 319.50.
Rumours bubbled about a possible bonus share announcement by the firm ahead of its annual shareholders meeting on June 26.
The speculation has been around since chairman Dhirubhai Ambani hinted at the firm's last shareholders' meeting that a bonus issue could be forthcoming, analysts said.
Reliance shares have jumped nearly 60 percent in 1997, favoured by massive capacity additions, high exposure to India's demand growth and increasing ventures in the oil, power and telecoms sectors.
"There has been a sharp run-up in the stock in the last fortnight. Action has temporarily shifted to other topline stocks," one dealer said.
